page.title: 10A DYMCHURCH LANDSCAPE
page.content: A network of dykes across Romney Marsh helps to save this low-lying area from flooding. The dykes are an important part of our lives. We love their changing moods and contrasting characters. Dykes can be dirty and dangerous, they are cleaned out by a big crane, sludging through the smelly water. Some dykes are narrow and less than one metre deep. These usually dry up in the Summer. Wider sections are like a bright green carpet where we can sail a dinghy. The dykes provide a home for fish, water flies, water snails and all kinds of weeds. We enjoy fishing from the banks for roach and tiddlers like stickleback and minnows. Eels can be caught by pulling in weeds. Areas of the banks are scattered with wild flowers, shaded by hawthorn and elderberry bushes.
